'''Jacques Laudy''' (7 April 1907 - 28 July 1993) was a Belgian [[comics]] artist, who contributed to the early issues of the weekly ''[[Tintin (magazine)|Tintin]]'' magazine.
Jacques Laudy was born in [[Schaarbeek]] in 1907 as the son of the painter Jean Laudy. He worked mainly as a painter, illustrator and comics artist. Laudy had started his career as an artist for ''[[Bravo (Belgian magazine)|Bravo]]'', together with ''[[Spirou (magazine)|Spirou]]'' one of the leading Belgian comics magazines before and during [[World War II]]. One of the other artists there was [[Edgar Pierre Jacobs]], who had first met Laudy in the 1920s and who would become a lifelong friend.<ref>{{cite book|last=BiermÃ©|first=Philippe|title=Chez Edgar P.: Jacobs: dans l'intimitÃ© du pÃ¨re de Blake et Mortimer|year=2004|publisher=Editions du CEFAL|isbn= 9782871301912|pages=112|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=L2jVCRca0x0C&pg=PA53&dq=%22Jacques+Laudy%22&hl=en&ei=_PMhTI7LK5zfsAajpvHlBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CEEQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=%22Laudy%22&f=false|accessdate=23 June 2010|language=French}}</ref> Laudy was the physical example for Blake, one of the main characters of Jacobs' ''[[Blake and Mortimer]]''.<ref>{{cite book|last=Gaudez|first=Florent|title=Les arts moyens aujourd'hui: actes du colloque international d'Albi, 30-31 mars, 1er avril 2006, Volume 1|year=2008|publisher=Editions L'Harmattan|isbn=9782296058705|pages=350|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=YorGsNMDkTYC&pg=PA218&dq=%22Jacques+Laudy%22&hl=en&ei=f_ohTMeBKoiosQaDge3lBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCQQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=%22Jacques%20Laudy%22&f=false|accessdate=23 June 2010|page=218|language=French}}</ref>
[[HergÃ©]] asked Laudy as one of the first artists, together with Jacobs, [[Paul Cuvelier]], and [[Jacques van Melkebeke]], to fill the new magazine ''[[Tintin (magazine)|Tintin]]''. Laudy created ''The Legend of the Four [[Renaud de Montauban|Aymon Brothers]]''.<ref>{{cite book|last=Assouline|first=Pierre|title=HergÃ©: The Man Who Created Tintin|year=2009|publisher=Oxford University Press US|isbn=9780195397598|pages=288|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=YsyEMjvdYJgC&pg=PA120&dq=%22Jacques+Laudy%22&hl=en&ei=_PMhTI7LK5zfsAajpvHlBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22%20Laudy%22&f=false|authorlink=Pierre Assouline|accessdate=23 June 2010|page=122}}</ref> His only real series was ''Hassan et Kadour'', while the rest of his oeuvre consisted mainly of one-offs, stories that didn't belong in a series. This lack of a series and lack of album publication also meant that Laudy never became as well known as the others.<ref>{{cite news|last=Couvreur|first=Daniel|title= L'auteur de bande dessinÃ©e Jacques Laudy amait conter Etterbeek le Royaume d'Otterbeek, Ã l'Est de Broebeleer|url=http://archives.lesoir.be/l-auteur-de-bande-dessinee-jacques-laudy-aimait-conter-_t-19931216-Z07LFJ.html|accessdate=23 June 2010|newspaper=Le Soir|date=16 December 1993|language=French}}</ref> In 1992, he wa the focus of a retrospective exhibition at the [[Belgian Centre for Comic Strip Art]].
His main interest outside art was music. From 1928 on, he was a collector and maker of [[Pipe (instrument)|pipes]], mainly Scottish ones. An instrument made by him in 1940 is in the collection of the [[Musical Instrument Museum (Brussels)|Musical Instrument Museum of Brussels]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Haine|first=Malou|title=Dictionnaire des facteurs d'instruments de musique en Wallonie et Ã Bruxelles du 9e siÃ¨cle Ã nos jours|year=1986|publisher=Mardaga|isbn= 9782870092507|pages=785|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=hIJlukgYzFUC&pg=PA245&dq=%22Jacques+Laudy%22&hl=en&ei=_PMhTI7LK5zfsAajpvHlBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22Jacques%20Laudy%22&f=false|accessdate=23 June 2010|page=245|language=French}}</ref>
==Bibliography== Many works by Laudy have never been published as albums and are only available in the magazines they originally appeared in. This is a list of those comics or illustrations that were published as a book eventually.
*''Les mameluks de Bonaparte'', editions R.T.P., 1975, published in Dutch as ''Soldaten van Napoleon'' by Brabantia Nostra the same year *''De dief van Bagdad'', Panda, 1978 *''De vrolijcke en heerlijcke daden van Keizer Karel en andere vertelsels'', Jonas, 1979 *''Silhouetten'', Blues, 1981 *''Le Royaume d'Edgar J.'', Himalaya / Magic Strip, 1993, published in Dutch as ''Het rijk van Edgar J.''by Loempia the same year
